text: The word of the Lord that came to Joel son of Pethuel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Hear this, you elders;
    listen, all who live in the land.
Has anything like this ever happened in your days
    or in the days of your ancestors?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Tell it to your children,
    and let your children tell it to their children,
    and their children to the next generation.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Wake up, you drunkards, and weep!
    Wail, all you drinkers of wine;
wail because of the new wine,
    for it has been snatched from your lips.
speaker: Narrator

text:
A nation has invaded my land,
    a mighty army without number;
it has the teeth of a lion,
    the fangs of a lioness.
speaker: Narrator

text:
It has laid waste my vines
    and ruined my fig-trees.
It has stripped off their bark
    and thrown it away,
    leaving their branches white.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Mourn like a virgin in sackcloth
    grieving for the betrothed of her youth.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Grain offerings and drink offerings
    are cut off from the house of the Lord.
The priests are in mourning,
    those who minister before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The fields are ruined,
    the ground is dried up;
the grain is destroyed,
    the new wine is dried up,
    the olive oil fails.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Despair, you farmers,
    wail, you vine growers;
grieve for the wheat and the barley,
    because the harvest of the field is destroyed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The vine is dried up
    and the fig-tree is withered;
the pomegranate, the palm and the apple tree –
    all the trees of the field – are dried up.
Surely the people’s joy
    is withered away.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Declare a holy fast;
    call a sacred assembly.
Summon the elders
    and all who live in the land
to the house of the Lord your God,
    and cry out to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Has not the food been cut off
    before our very eyes –
joy and gladness
    from the house of our God?
speaker: Narrator

text:
The seeds are shrivelled
    beneath the clods.
The storehouses are in ruins,
    the granaries have been broken down,
    for the grain has dried up.
speaker: Narrator

text:
How the cattle moan!
    The herds mill about
because they have no pasture;
    even the flocks of sheep are suffering.
speaker: Narrator

text:
To you, Lord, I call,
    for fire has devoured the pastures in the wilderness
    and flames have burned up all the trees of the field.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Blow the trumpet in Zion;
    sound the alarm on my holy hill.
Let all who live in the land tremble,
    for the day of the Lord is coming.
It is close at hand –
speaker: Narrator

text:
a day of darkness and gloom,
    a day of clouds and blackness.
Like dawn spreading across the mountains
    a large and mighty army comes,
such as never was in ancient times
    nor ever will be in ages to come.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Before them fire devours,
    behind them a flame blazes.
Before them the land is like the garden of Eden,
    behind them, a desert waste –
    nothing escapes them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They have the appearance of horses;
    they gallop along like cavalry.
speaker: Narrator

text:
With a noise like that of chariots
    they leap over the mountaintops,
like a crackling fire consuming stubble,
    like a mighty army drawn up for battle.
speaker: Narrator

text:
At the sight of them, nations are in anguish;
    every face turns pale.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They charge like warriors;
    they scale walls like soldiers.
They all march in line,
    not swerving from their course.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They do not jostle each other;
    each marches straight ahead.
They plunge through defences
    without breaking ranks.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Before them the earth shakes,
    the heavens tremble,
the sun and moon are darkened,
    and the stars no longer shine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord thunders
    at the head of his army;
his forces are beyond number,
    and mighty is the army that obeys his command.
The day of the Lord is great;
    it is dreadful.
    Who can endure it?
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Even now,’ declares the Lord,
    ‘return to me with all your heart,
    with fasting and weeping and mourning.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Rend your heart
    and not your garments.
Return to the Lord your God,
    for he is gracious and compassionate,
slow to anger and abounding in love,
    and he relents from sending calamity.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who knows? He may turn and relent
    and leave behind a blessing –
grain offerings and drink offerings
    for the Lord your God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Blow the trumpet in Zion,
    declare a holy fast,
    call a sacred assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Gather the people,
    consecrate the assembly;
bring together the elders,
    gather the children,
    those nursing at the breast.
Let the bridegroom leave his room
    and the bride her chamber.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Let the priests, who minister before the Lord,
    weep between the portico and the altar.
Let them say, ‘Spare your people, Lord.
    Do not make your inheritance an object of scorn,
    a byword among the nations.
Why should they say among the peoples,
    ‘‘Where is their God?”’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then the Lord was jealous for his land
    and took pity on his people.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord replied to them:
‘I am sending you grain, new wine and olive oil,
    enough to satisfy you fully;
never again will I make you
    an object of scorn to the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I will drive the northern horde far from you,
    pushing it into a parched and barren land;
its eastern ranks will drown in the Dead Sea
    and its western ranks in the Mediterranean Sea.
And its stench will go up;
    its smell will rise.’
Surely he has done great things!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Do not be afraid, you wild animals,
    for the pastures in the wilderness are becoming green.
The trees are bearing their fruit;
    the fig-tree and the vine yield their riches.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Be glad, people of Zion,
    rejoice in the Lord your God,
for he has given you the autumn rains
    because he is faithful.
He sends you abundant showers,
    both autumn and spring rains, as before.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The threshing-floors will be filled with grain;
    the vats will overflow with new wine and oil.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I will repay you for the years the locusts have eaten –
    the great locust and the young locust,
    the other locusts and the locust swarm –
my great army that I sent among you.
speaker: Narrator

text:
You will have plenty to eat, until you are full,
    and you will praise the name of the Lord your God,
    who has worked wonders for you;
never again will my people be shamed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then you will know that I am in Israel,
    that I am the Lord your God,
    and that there is no other;
never again will my people be shamed.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘And afterwards,
    I will pour out my Spirit on all people.
Your sons and daughters will prophesy,
    your old men will dream dreams,
    your young men will see visions.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Even on my servants, both men and women,
    I will pour out my Spirit in those days.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will show wonders in the heavens
    and on the earth,
    blood and fire and billows of smoke.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sun will be turned to darkness
    and the moon to blood
    before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And everyone who calls
    on the name of the Lord will be saved;
for on Mount Zion and in Jerusalem
    there will be deliverance,
    as the Lord has said,
even among the survivors
    whom the Lord calls.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘In those days and at that time,
    when I restore the fortunes of Judah and Jerusalem,
speaker: Narrator

text:
I will gather all nations
    and bring them down to the Valley of Jehoshaphat.
There I will put them on trial
    for what they did to my inheritance, my people Israel,
because they scattered my people among the nations
    and divided up my land.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: ‘Now what have you against me, Tyre and Sidon and all you regions of Philistia? Are you repaying me for something I have done? If you are paying me back, I will swiftly and speedily return on your own heads what you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: For you took my silver and my gold and carried off my finest treasures to your temples.
speaker: Narrator

text: You sold the people of Judah and Jerusalem to the Greeks, that you might send them far from their homeland.
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘See, I am going to rouse them out of the places to which you sold them, and I will return on your own heads what you have done.
speaker: Narrator

text: I will sell your sons and daughters to the people of Judah, and they will sell them to the Sabeans, a nation far away.’ The Lord has spoken.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Proclaim this among the nations:
    Prepare for war!
Rouse the warriors!
    Let all the fighting men draw near and attack.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Beat your ploughshares into swords
    and your pruning hooks into spears.
Let the weakling say,
    ‘I am strong!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Come quickly, all you nations from every side,
    and assemble there.
Bring down your warriors, Lord!
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
Swing the sickle,
    for the harvest is ripe.
Come, trample the grapes,
    for the winepress is full
    and the vats overflow –
so great is their wickedness!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Multitudes, multitudes
    in the valley of decision!
For the day of the Lord is near
    in the valley of decision.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The sun and moon will be darkened,
    and the stars no longer shine.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Lord will roar from Zion
    and thunder from Jerusalem;
    the earth and the heavens will tremble.
But the Lord will be a refuge for his people,
    a stronghold for the people of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘Then you will know that I, the Lord your God,
    dwell in Zion, my holy hill.
Jerusalem will be holy;
    never again will foreigners invade her.
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘In that day the mountains will drip new wine,
    and the hills will flow with milk;
    all the ravines of Judah will run with water.
A fountain will flow out of the Lord’s house
    and will water the valley of acacias.
speaker: Narrator

text:
But Egypt will be desolate,
    Edom a desert waste,
because of violence done to the people of Judah,
    in whose land they shed innocent blood.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Judah will be inhabited for ever
    and Jerusalem through all generations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Shall I leave their innocent blood unavenged?
    No, I will not.’
The Lord dwells in Zion!
speaker: Narrator
